Let $G$ be a group and $S \subset G$ a subset. The centralizer of $S$ in $G$ is given by $Z_{S}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in S\} .$
The center of a group $G$ is defined as the centralizer of $G$, i.e., as $Z=Z_{G}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in G\} .$
Does the concept of a/an Centralizer need to be defined for a definition of a/an Center to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of the Center of a group $G$ explicitly states that it is the centralizer of $G$. This means that the concept of the Center ($Z_G$) is directly defined using the concept of the Centralizer. The Center is described as the set of all elements in $G$ that commute with every element of $G$, which is exactly the definition of the centralizer of the entire group $G$. Therefore, understanding and defining the Centralizer is essential for the definition of the Center to make sense, as the Center is a specific case of the Centralizer where the subset $S$ is the entire group $G$. Without the concept of the Centralizer, the definition of the Center as given would not be complete or understandable.
